context: Drought conditions appeared to influence both basal emission rates and the shape of the temperature response. During drought conditions on August 11, basal I L from the same Q. rubra leaf measured in June decreased by ∼30% and showed very little response to increasing leaf temperature above 30 °C (Fig. 2). Despite prolonged slightly negative values of net photosynthesis (A), substantial amounts of isoprene were emitted at higher T L from Q. rubra and Q. velutina in Fig. 2, suggesting the possibility that isoprene was produced from a source other than recently fixed carbon. On August 9, another Q. rubra leaf on a different tree was held at approximately constant temperature and PPFD (33 ± 2 °C and 2000 μmol m−2 s−1) using the Li-Cor 6400 (Fig. 3 ). At 10 AM, when the first measurements were made, isoprene was emitted at 40 μgC g−1 h−1 but was already declining steeply, and it is likely the early morning peak in emissions was missed. Isoprene continued to decline steadily, to 20 μgC g−1 h−1 by 1 PM, and fell to 13 μgC g−1 h−1 through the afternoon (5 PM).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 2-methylbuta-1,3-diene, also known as isoprene, is discussed in relation to its emission from Quercus rubra leaves under drought conditions. The text suggests that isoprene may be produced from a source other than recently fixed carbon, indicating a potential metabolic pathway that does not rely solely on carbon fixation. This implies a relationship between isoprene production and carbon, as isoprene is a carbon-based compound, but the specific dynamics of their interaction are not deeply explored.
